title: Hurt Nationals pitcher Scherzer to miss World Series start
text:
Washington (AFP) – Washington Nationals star pitcher Max Scherzer was scratched from his scheduled start Sunday in game five of the World Series due to spasms in his right neck and trapezius muscle.

The 35-year-old won game one of the best-of-seven Major League Baseball final and his absence left the Nationals at a major disadvantage with the series deadlocked 2-2.

“For Max to miss a game like this, he has got to be hurting,” Nationals manager Dave Martinez said.

“He’s really upset and wants to be out there with his teammates.”

Scherzer went 11-7 with a 2.92 earned-run average and led all major league pitchers with 7.364 strikeouts for every walk issued this season.

Scherzer made his seventh consecutive All-Star Game appearance this year. He’s a three-time winner of the Cy Young Award as top pitcher and a three-time National League strikeouts leader.

While Scherzer had been on the injured list in July with a strained upper back muscle, this latest injury was unrelated to the earlier one, Martinez said.

“He was in there with the training staff yesterday getting all kinds of treatment,” Martinez said. “He woke up today and it was a lot worse. He told them right away he was really hurting.”

Scheduled game six starter Stephen Strasburg, 4-0 in the playoffs, will remain set for Tuesday’s contest in Houston, Martinez said, with Scherzer possible if healthy for a seventh game start Wednesday if necessary.

“As of right now I’d leave Stephen starting game six,” Martinez said. “If we get to game seven, Max starts game seven.”

Joe Ross, who has thrown only two innings in one game with one hit allowed during the Nationals’ surprise playoff run into the World Series, was named the game-five starter.

The 26-year-old US right-hander went 4-4 this season in nine starts and 27 appearances. He allowed 41 runs on 74 hits over 64 innings while walking 33 batters and striking out 57.

“He’s such a great competitor and great athlete,” Strasburg said. “I trust in his ability to compete.”

Martinez said Scherzer would continue to receive treatment but was unhappy aboiut missing what could have been a career-defining start.

“He’s really upset about it. I’ve never seen Max this quiet,” Martinez said.

Lacking Strasburg means extra duty not only for Ross but the Nats’ relievers, including rested ace late-inning specialists Sean Doolittle and Daniel Hudson.

“We’ll let him go,” Martinez said of Ross. “He can get up to 70-80 pitches.”

Strasburg said he was never truly a candidate to fill in for “Mad Max” on short rest.

“I don’t think it ever really was an idea,” Strasburg said. “I threw (in the) bullpen yesterday. I’m kind of at that point where I’m preparing for game six.”

– ‘Got to be pretty bad’ –

While many players are hurting since they began training camp eight months ago, the loss of Scherzer could be catastrophic for a team that has squandered a 2-0 series lead with two home losses.

“Guys were talking in the clubhouse. I think everybody is dealing with the effects of a long season,” Strasburg said. “You just focus on what you can control. Sometimes things are out of your control.”

Houston’s Justin Verlander, the game two loser and scheduled game six starter, was a former teammate of Scherzer in Detroit.

“It has got to be pretty bad,” said Verlander. “He’s a competitor, always wanted to have the ball. Given the situation, I assume it’s not good.”

Despite not having an expected top pitcher’s duel with Houston’s Gerrit Cole, Verlander said Scherzer’s absence should not dim the World Series.

“I don’t think it should take anything away from the series,” Verlander said. “We’re not robots. We’re human. It’s a long season. Things go wrong all the time. Being on the biggest stage brings more attention to the adversity.”
